Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Physiological and Biochemical Underpinnings of Thermal Tolerance in Antarctic Notothenioid Fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ocean surrounding Antarctica is home to an extraordinary assemblage of fishes, dominated by a single group that are extremely well-suited to life in icy waters and which are of significant ecological importance there. Of great concern is the capacity of these fishes to withstand increases in temperature as the region of the Western Antarctic Peninsula warms at a rate faster than any other area in the Southern hemisphere. One particular group of Antarctic fishes, known as the icefishes, are particularly vulnerable to increases in temperature because unlike all other vertebrates on earth, icefishes are white-blooded due to their lack of the oxygen-binding protein hemoglobin. This greatly reduces their capacity to transport and deliver oxygen to tissues compared to red-blooded Antarctic fishes. Previous studies have shown that icefishes are indeed less tolerant to elevations in temperature but the underlying factors are completely unknown. Additionally, it is not understood if red- or white-blooded Antarctic fishes can adjust, or acclimate, to modest increases in temperature, similar to those changes in temperature the animals might experience as the earth warms. The investigators will determine if heart function and/or nervous system function limits thermal tolerance of Antarctic fishes, and will determine their capacity to acclimate to warmer temperatures. The project will further the NSF goal of training new generations of scientists by training graduate and undergraduate students. In addition, the project will collaborate with a high school biology teacher from a school which serves a largely minority student body. The students will learn about the marine environment, and will construct a camera to be used in the field to learn more about Antarctic fishes. Two students and the teacher will also attend a summer marine biology internship program.

Antarctic fishes within the suborder Notothenioidei (called "notothenioids") are among the organisms on earth least able to deal with changes in temperature. The hemoglobinless icefish are even less able to withstand temperature changes than are red-blooded notothenioids. While this is well documented, the underlying physiological and biochemical mechanisms responsible are unknown. The investigators will test the hypotheses that cardiac work is significantly greater in icefishes compared to red-blooded species, and that as temperature increases, the greater cardiac work of icefishes, coupled with reduced blood oxygen-carrying capacity, results in cardiac failure at a lower temperature compared to red-blooded species. They also hypothesize that neuronal function limits thermal tolerance of red-blooded notothenioids. These hypotheses will be tested using a wide variety of experiments. For example, the investigators will measure heart rate concurrently with critical thermal maximum. They will also characterize metabolic and gene-expression responses to elevated temperature and determine if mitochondrial function contributes to thermal tolerance using a variety of techniques. To determine if neuronal function limits thermal tolerance they will quantify behavioral responses to warming of whole animals and to warming of only the brain area. They will also determine if acclimation to warmer temperatures impacts heart function and they will measure activities of a variety of enzymes from central metabolic pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A remarkable assemblage of fishes inhabits the Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica, many of which are found nowhere else on earth. The Antarctic fish fauna is dominated by members of the Notothenioidei suborder, which includes both red-blooded fishes that have hemoglobin to transport oxygen, and the unique icefishes, whose blood is startlingly white due to their lack of hemoglobin. These fishes have evolved for approximately 20 million years in an icy cold, oxygen-rich environment where water temperatures historically have hovered near -1?C with little seasonal variation. Yet like all other places on earth, the Southern Ocean is rapidly warming. As a result of their long evolution at cold temperature, Antarctic fishes are exquisitely sensitive to increases in temperature, especially the icefishes. Survival in a warming world will require adjustments in physiological and biochemical processes to accommodate an increase in temperature (thermal plasticity), and sufficient genetic diversity within populations (adaptive capacity). Our studies sought to characterize the thermal plasticity of Antarctic fishes in key traits that constrain thermal tolerance to better assess their ability to survive in a warming climate. Our work focused on the heart because prior studies in temperate fishes identified cardiac function as a key trait limiting thermal tolerance.

 

We determined that cardiac function contributes to thermal tolerance in both red-and white-blooded Antarctic fishes, with hearts of the more thermally tolerant red-blooded species Notothenia coriiceps becoming persistently arrhythmic at a higher temperature than that of the icefish, Chaenocephalus aceratus. Encouragingly we found that icefishes have a greater capacity to modulate cardiac function than previously thought, significantly increasing both heart rate and cardiac output in response to an acute increase in temperature. We determined that thermal limits of cardiac performance are influenced by cardiac mitochondrial function and the ability to maintain ATP levels, which are higher in the red-blooded N. coriiceps compared to the icefish C. aceratus. Cardiac performance is also associated with membrane integrity. Membranes from hearts of icefishes become leakier at a lower temperature compared to red-blooded species, which may compromise the activity of proteins embedded in the membranes that regulate cardiac contractility.

 

Next, we acclimated the red-blooded N. coriiceps to 5 ?C for 6 weeks to assess thermal plasticity of cardiac performance. Encouragingly we found that cardiac performance of N. coriiceps improves with warm acclimation. Hearts of warm-acclimated N. coriiceps failed at a higher temperature and maintained a higher cardiac output than animals held at ambient temperature. The improved cardiac performance in warm-acclimated fishes is associated with improved capacity of mitochondria to synthesize ATP and membrane remodeling in the heart so that membrane integrity is maintained at higher temperatures.

 

Although our results indicate that Antarctic fishes have retained some degree of thermal plasticity to cope with climate warming, we found that not all traits are malleable. Rates of oxygen consumption in warm-acclimated N. coriiceps are higher than that of animals held at ambient temperature and energy stores in the liver in the form of triacylglycerol are lower, suggesting energy resources may be diverted away from some processes such as reproduction in order to support basic metabolic demand. Also, we found that the ability of Antarctic fishes to respond to low oxygen (hypoxia) that accompanies warming may be compromised because of a genetic mutation in a key protein that regulates the hypoxia response pathway.

 

Our work has had broad impacts within our communities and beyond through our mentoring of the next generation of scientists. We have engaged two graduate, five undergraduate (including one Native Alaskan), and many high school students in our research, providing career guidance, training in biochemical and physiological techniques, and enhancing their understanding of polar biology. The NSF-funded program PolarTREC helped to support our collaboration with high school teacher, Paula Dell, at Lindblom Math and Science Academy in Chicago, IL, which has a large African American (69%) and Hispanic (26%) population. Students from Lindblom constructed an underwater camera (Fish Spy) that was deployed during our 2017 field season and permitted us to observe Antarctic fishes in their natural habitat. The students' work was highlighted in a variety of news media outlets, including ABC News, the Chicago Tribune, and Fox News. Additionally, two students from Lindblom Team Fish Spy attended a two-week marine biology program, OceansWide, where they became certified divers and learned about the marine environment.

 

We've shared results from our work and raised awareness about the impacts of human activities and climate change on the Antarctic ecosystem through presentations at scientific conferences, peer-reviewed publications, and engagement with the general public. Examples of the latter include a Science for the People podcast about Antarctic fishes, a study board and webinar created in collaboration with Polar-ICE that provided resources about Antarctic fishes for teachers, and a publication for kids entitled Icefish Diaries, written by Paula Dell from Lindblom Math and Science Academy and published by Cricket.
